case: A 21-year-old Black with binge alcohol use presents with acute-onset, severe, crampy abdominal pain, symptoms concerning for peritonitis, with associated nausea and vomiting, and is found to have tachycardia, tachypnea, and and a fever.
differential: Mesenteric ischemia (less likely at this age, but possible with severe symptoms)
Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (especially if underlying liver disease)
Gastrointestinal perforation due to other causes (e.g., trauma, ingestion of foreign body)

case: A 21-year-old Black with binge alcohol use presents with acute-onset, severe, crampy abdominal pain, symptoms concerning for peritonitis, with associated nausea and vomiting, and is found to have tachycardia, tachypnea, and and a fever.
differential: Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (if underlying liver disease)
Acute hepatitis (alcoholic or viral, with peritonitis)
Acute diverticulitis with perforation (less common at this age but possible)
